title: A Man Helping Young People Find Jobs
summary: Alan Milburn is a man who used to be a government minister. He is working to help young people who are not in school, work, or training, called Neets. There are almost a million young people aged 16 to 24 in this group, which is the highest number in over 10 years. More than half of them are not looking for work. Milburn says this is a big problem, especially in the north-east of England where it is hard to find jobs. He calls it a catastrophe because it affects society, the economy, and politics. Milburn grew up in a poor area and had a tough school, so he understands the challenges. He supports a local youth project called Patchwork, where a youth worker named Karl says the term Neet is negative and blames people unfairly. They want to find better solutions to help young people get opportunities.

background_read: This article is about young people who are not going to school, working, or training for jobs. This is a big problem in some places like the north-east of England. Alan Milburn, who used to work for the government, is trying to help because he grew up in a poor area and knows it is hard. He and others want to find ways to give young people better chances instead of blaming them.
Article_Structure: WHO: Alan Milburn, a former government minister, and Karl Maughan Gilbert, a youth worker.
WHAT: They are working to help young people not in education, employment, or training (Neets).
WHERE: In the north-east of England, especially in places like Benwell, Newcastle.
WHY: Because many young people are struggling to find jobs, and it is causing big problems for society and the economy.

perspectives.description: He sees the Neet problem as a catastrophe and wants to help based on his personal experience growing up poor.
He thinks the term Neet is negative and unfair because it blames young people instead of looking at bigger issues.
